comments.commentBody:
The Ferguson shooting and Saturday's shooting in Cleveland of a 12-year old boy each indicate that police are responding to both of the following situations with lethal force.

Case A Police encounter a violent crime in progress or threatened.

Case B Police engage someone, no crime in progress, public not threatened, armed status of person engaged known or unknown.

Training and protocols for Case B need to be overhauled, as in wait for backup and be prepared to be use nonlethal, standoff force if needed, such as a tranquilize dart.

Different people express their frustrations in unique ways, which they feel will have the most impact.  Looting and destruction of property is given inordinate importance in these type of cases.  The news wires first report of this story was about the looting and destruction of property, followed by the killing of an unarmed African American teenager by a white police officer.  The killing of an African American teenager by a police officer was not newsworthy in and of itself.  The destruction of property and looting was what got the news wires' attention and the attention of conservatives.  This emphasis on the importance of property over the life of an African American makes the grand jury's verdict predictable.
It is not pleasant to see the sausage being made.

Brian, the old 80-20 rule applies again.  The 20% who mess things up that takes 80% of the time, people, and resources to fix.  Most of our problems have always been that 80% don't even take the time to vote, let alone be part of the fixing.

The tragedy of Officer Wilson and Michael Brown requires no additional comment - it seems everything that can be said about it has already been said 100 times over.

However, watching the news unfold over the ensuing riots, I can't help but wonder if the riots are a symptom of something other than racial injustice. When I see reports of looters raiding a mobile phone store for the electronics and a Walgreens for the alcohol, I can't help but think to myself that the looting isn't an expression of frustration about racial injustice - it's merely an excuse to smash-and-grab in the protective anonymity of a faceless mob.

Indeed, there are many protesting tonight with understandable frustration. Such a shame that destructive greed has to inject itself into the response, poisoning what might have otherwise been harnessed into productive ends.
And you are not willing to take the decision of a grand jury as being unbiased and having seen the evidence. You are calling the members of that jury racist, by what standard?
In other words, you want to grand jury to throw up its hands and say it's not competent to make a decision? In that case, what would make a trial jury more competent?

Let's see... the officer had just been attacked IN HIS CAR before it spilled out into the street, THEN the guy charges him from 50 feet, then 40 feet, then 30 feet, then 20 feet.... so, when do YOU shoot?

That's the problem: the DA moved the matter to a secret proceeding.
Rather than doing a preliminary hearing, he chose to do it in secret where he controlled exactly what got presented to the grand jury.

Before you start saying about how fair justice is in this country, maybe the evidence will show that the justice system was used unfairly here.

"A disgusting miscarriage of justice."

Please cite evidence which supports your statement.
The trial was secret, yet you know that "excessive evidence" was presented?  Were you a fly on the wall?

What? There is so much of a disproportianate rate of stopping for traffic offenses, that it is called "driving while black." Perhaps you are also not aware of the "stop and frisk policy" especially beloved of Guiliani and Bloomberg?
It is called harassment. It is called "fear of young black men." It is partially caused by the laws for the "war on drugs." Read the book "The New Jim Crow". It has a lot of history about the war on drugs of Reagan, and even Clinton, and Bush too.
Not a shoplifter. A strong-armed robber who attacked the clerk. It's on video.

the distrust between the African American community and the police have roots so deep....it will be almost virtually impossible to heal it. I looked at the autopsy photos....Mr Brown Im sorry to say was acting like a kid...a big foolish kid......Mr Wilson on the other hand a person of authority..train to defuse criminal situations..paid to protect and serve....the bullets he fired at Mr Brown....unless he was going for the whole shoot em up Tex..thing...were inexcusable....he could have just fired one at the knee or both knees to disable him and waited for back up....but then to leave the body in the street for what was it 4 hours or some ridiculous amount of time...like an roadkill...again. Inexcusable....and inhumane

Everyone who was paying attention knew a lack of criminal charges would result in what we are seeing right now in Ferguson. So what in the world was the prosecutor thinking when he came out and spoke without sympathy or understanding of the concerns of some members of his community. 'It was the media's fault', 'it was the differing eye witness accounts', it was Michael Brown's fault.  And then he makes the announcement at night. I pray for the success of the non violent organizers in the Ferguson now. Its a sad day, poorly managed.

How does someone who has been shot multiple times react when his killer chases him and continues to shot him?

There is no way Michael Brown charged him. A charge constitutes that you are healthy, strong and you are going to take down whatever you are charging. Michael Brown was bleeding from multiple gun shot wounds, in serious pain, probable internal bleeding and afraid for his life. Yet the murdering officer and 12 secret jurors thought that an unarmed dying teenager would charge an armed and shooting police officer. Wow!!! That is completely illogical and does not pass the smell test.

Not sure if it'd matter that much.

"A more comprehensive analysis exists: Dr. Klinger and Dr. Rosenfeld, among others, examined all 230 instances over 10 years in which officers of the St. Louis police fired their weapons (the city’s police, in contrast to the police in Ferguson involved in Mr. Brown’s shooting).
...
But most interesting, perhaps, was the race of the officers who fired their weapons. About two-thirds were white, and one-third black — effectively identical to the racial composition of the St. Louis Police Department as a whole. In this study, at least, firing at a black suspect was an equal-opportunity decision."

http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/31/sunday-review/race-and-police-shooting...
What is injustice is the very possibility that an unarmed man could be shot dead (over and over) with impunity in a nation of laws.

sdavidc9:

The unifying leader will understand that members of Congress are, in fact, stubborn. That they got where they are by being more stubborn than anyone else and more politically ruthless and adept than anyone.

The unifying leader starts with an understanding of the dynamics of Congress, how it operates and what it takes to maneuver within it to achieve his or her desired outcomes.

The foolish leader will believe that he will "transform" them based on nothing but his own hubris.

The childish leader will get frustrated, starting taking potshots at Congress in public when things don't go his way and then take his toys and retreat to the White House.

AACNY
The unifying leader the right wing of the USA is looking for will be more in the mold of Francisco Franco, Benito Mussolini or Augusto Pinochet. He will rise up from the midst of the lynch mob much like Reagan in the early 50s by betraying those who put their trust in him and he will collaborate the paranoia of the the McCarthys and Nixons just as did our esteemed Ronald. He will go to Philadelphia Mississippi and congratulate the lynch mob on a job well done. "That my friend" is leadership.

"Members of Congress might be thrilled to have someone who could actually work with them."

And Mr. Obama might be thrilled to have someone who could actually work with HIM. The Republicans, before Obama was even inaugurated, decided to make it their strategy to be obstructionist. Obama didn't have a chance.

Mr. Brooks will be lambasted for not blaming one side and for implying the president is not that leader, but he is absolutely right. The unifying leader will be someone very, very different from anyone in leadership now.

Given all the difficulties the current Congress has experienced with this president, the next president might need only possess enough skill to develop relationships, collaborate with others, and allow them to get enough things done to keep their constituents happy.

It might not take all that much. Members of Congress might be thrilled to have someone who could actually work with them.
You are also ignorant of the grand jury system, and the article in the Constitution that makes it mandatory.

John, I think Aredee's point is that "all the evidence" could have been heard out in the open, with the addition of legal counsel representing the family of the murdered boy. Maybe the prosecutor was not lying, but he certainly did a nice job of steering justice in the direction he thought most appropriate.
What is your opinion of what prosecutors are paid to do?
Grand jurors (at least in NY) have the right to question witnesses and even ask for additional witnesses to testify.

I am only a layperson, but isn't the "evidence" presented before a grand jury limited to that evidence that the prosecutor wants to present?

I can concede that some testimony was contradictory, but isn't this better presented in an open jury trial, with the advocates of both the prosecution and the defense able to present evidence and rebuttal as approved by a judge?

I wanted to believe in this grand jury process, but the manner in which it was undertaken leads me to believe that justice was not done. This was in effect a secret trial in which the outcome seems to be predetermined.

And I do hope I'm wrong, but I'm afraid I'm right.

I've raised three children and have intimately known dozens more, and make no mistake, an 18 year old is still a very immature, unformed person.  The legal age of majority determines only when parents are no longer required by law to support their children or be responsible for their behavior.   Though that arbitrary line does make the teenager totally responsible for his/her actions, it does NOT confer or assume the wisdom and restraint of adulthood.  Michael Brown was just another dumb, immature kid who will never get the chance to outgrow his foolishness.  Tragic.
"Murder"?
Finally, a voice of sanity.

He said that the only close range wound was the graze on his thumb. When he was listing the various shots, he did indicate a range of distances and my recollection is that the last, shots came when he was over 50 feet away.

no, this is the time and place to get sad, and indignant, and perhaps, mad, about racial injustice. Try reading the book " The New Jim Crow," by Michelle Alexander.
"The system worked the way it should..." you say. The way it always has, because we European-American Caucasian people have the power, the wealth and the judicial system to keep that power.
Both North and South made great profits from slavery, which was in both the North and the South. Slavery was outlawed in NY state as late as 1827. Though slavery persisted until 1865 here in the rest of the country.
We are all still recovering from the trauma, and the prejudices of the slave holders, and of being enslaved.
We need reconciliation, truth telling , and healing. At Coming To The Table.org, we are, descendants of the enslaved, and descendants of slave holders, working together on healing.

"If this prosecutor had wanted an indictment, he could have gotten one, but he didn't."

A US Supreme Court opinion explained that a competent prosecutor can get an indictment "of a ham sandwich." A grand jury is not a real protection for a defendant nor a real assurance of justice. It is a tool, a pre-trial tool for the prosecutor, and then by its record for the defense. Evidence and actual guilt have almost nothing to do with that. Clearly the evidence in this case was confused enough that he could have if he wanted to. He didn't want to.

"He didn't do his job as an advocate for justice."

That is an entirely different question. He he chose this. He wanted this. But he knew all the evidence better than anyone. That he chose this outcome does not automatically mean he chose injustice. That we won't know until we know what he knew.

Meanwhile, the grand jury is something the politicians and police are hiding behind, to shift the appearance of their responsibility and choice onto it.
Thank you for your honesty in the face of the white majority making the laws to justify being judge, jury and executioner and controlling public opinion in the media.

As usual the "White Man " prevails. Sure there was no creditable evidence to show the officer had no probable cause to stop or even come back after telling the individual to stop walking in the street. Had it been a Latino Officer(senior) like myself or an African American,we would have been accused of harassment by our own Internal Affairs .
23 years on the street
The Chief from Cali
